questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with complaints of recurrent epigastric pain, progressive weight loss, and foul-smelling diarrhoea for the past 6 months. CT scan reveals pancreatic calcification and dilatation of the main pancreatic duct. Which of the following statements is false about his condition?

choices.text: It is more common in males
Abdominal pain is the most common symptom
Pain increases as destruction of the pancreas progresses

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic pancreatitis. Pain decreases or disappears as the destruction of the pancreas progress. This is called a burned-out pancreas. This correlates with the progression of disease from a mild or moderate stage to severe destruction of the pancreas.

Chronic pancreatitis is a progressive inflammatory disease in which there is an irreversible destruction of pancreatic tissue. It is more common in males, with a male: female ratio of 4:1. 

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Chronic Pancreatitis

Abdominal pain: most common symptom

  • Site:
    • If infectious foci are in the head of the pancreas, then epigastric and right subcostal pain is common;
    • If the infection is limited to the left side of the pancreas, left subcostal and back pain are seen.
  • Precipitated by food intake, thus weight loss is also seen.
  • Associated with nausea, vomiting

Exocrine insufficiency:

  • Precedes endocrine insufficiency
  • Correlates with morphological changes
  • Manifests with malabsorption symptoms: steatorrhea, diarrhea.
  • Manifests with signs and symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, such as bleeding, osteopenia, and osteoporosis: Severe cases

Endocrine insufficiency: Diabetes mellitus

questions.text: What is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Alcohol consumption is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis, accounting for 60–70% of the cases. Smoking increases the risk of alcohol-induced chronic pancreatitis.

Cystic fibrosis is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis in the pediatric age group.

Other causes of chronic pancreatitis include:
  • Pancreatic divisum
  • Annular pancreas
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Chronic duct obstruction
  • Autoimmune pancreatitis
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Tropical pancreatitis
  • Hereditary pancreatitis

Related Pearl: Pancreas - Most Commons

M/C cause of acute pancreatitis: Gallstones

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis: Alcohol

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis in children: Cystic fibrosis

M/C cause of pancreatic calcification: Alcohol

M/C congenital variant: Pancreas divisum

M/C site of thrombosis in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic vein 

M/C site of pseudoaneurysm in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic artery 

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Chronic Pancreatitis

Abdominal pain: most common symptom

  • Site:
    • If infectious foci are in the head of the pancreas, then epigastric and right subcostal pain is common;
    • If the infection is limited to the left side of the pancreas, left subcostal and back pain are seen.
  • Precipitated by food intake, thus weight loss is also seen.
  • Associated with nausea, vomiting

Exocrine insufficiency:

  • Precedes endocrine insufficiency
  • Correlates with morphological changes
  • Manifests with malabsorption symptoms: steatorrhea, diarrhea.
  • Manifests with signs and symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, such as bleeding, osteopenia, and osteoporosis: Severe cases

Endocrine insufficiency: Diabetes mellitus

Related Pearl: Resection and Hybrid Surgical Procedures for Chronic Pancreatitis

Beger’s procedure: Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (DPPHR)

  • The completed resection after transection of the pancreatic neck and subtotal removal of the pancreatic head, with preservation of the distal common bile duct and duodenum (Marked A).
  • Completion of the reconstruction of the anastomosis to the distal pancreas and to the proximal pancreatic rim by the same Roux limb of the jejunum.

Frey’s procedure:

  • The local resection of the pancreatic head with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (LR-LPJ) provides complete decompression of the entire pancreatic ductal system. Reconstruction is performed with a side-to-side Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy.

Warren’s modification of Beger’s procedure:

Berne modification (Beger + Frey) involves excavation of the central portion of the head without formal division of the neck.

(image below)

Hamburg modification of Frey’s procedure

Note:

Surgical treatments for chronic pancreatitis

Resection

  • Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Kausch–Whipple procedure)
  • Pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy (Traverso–Longmire)
  • Beger procedure
  • Near-total or total pancreatectomy

Decompression/Drainage

  • Duval procedure
  • Puestow–Gillesby procedure
  • Partington–Rochelle procedure (Puestow)
  • Izbicki procedure

Hybrid (resection+decompression)

  • Frey procedure
  • Hamburg modification
  • Berne modification

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the TIGAR-O classification?
questions.solution:
The T in the TIGAR-O classification stands for toxic-metabolic, not trauma.

The TIGAR-O classification system is an etiological approach to classify chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency.

Related Pearl: Chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency: TIGAR-O classification system

Toxic-metabolic

  • Alcoholic
  • Tobacco smoking
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Medications—phenacetin abuse
  • Toxins—organotin compounds (e.g., dibutyltin dichloride, DBTC)

Idiopathic

  • Early onset
  • Late onset
  • Tropical

Genetic

  • Cationic trypsinogen (PRSS1)
  • Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR)
  • Calcium-sensing receptor (CASR)
  • Chymotrypsin C gene (CTRC)
  • Pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor gene (SPINK1)

Autoimmune

  • Type 1 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis
  • IgG4 systemic
  • Type 2 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis

Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis

  • Postnecrotic (severe acute pancreatitis)
  • Recurrent acute pancreatitis
  • Vascular diseases/ischemia
  • Radiation-induced

Obstructive

  • Pancreas divisum
  • Duct obstruction (e.g., tumor)
  • Periampullary duodenal wall cysts
  • Posttraumatic pancreatic duct scars

questions.text: A young patient with recurrent abdominal pain and pancreatic calcification was found to have a mutation in SPINK1. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: Associated with high incidence of diabetes mellitus.
It can be distinguished from chronic alcoholic pancreatitis histologically.
Cassava ingestion is an etiological factor.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chronic pancreatitis with SPINK1 mutation is suggestive of tropical pancreatitis (nutritional pancreatitis). Tropical pancreatitis is histologically indistinguishable from chronic alcoholic pancreatitis.

Normally, if trypsinogen does become prematurely activated within the pancreas, it is inhibited by SPINK1 and then gets destroyed. A loss-of-function mutation in SPINK1 affects this process and predisposes to tropical pancreatitis.

Tropical pancreatitis is a form of idiopathic pancreatitis that begins at a young age and is usually seen in Indonesia, southern India (Kerala), and tropical Africa. It is associated with a high incidence of diabetes mellitus (a brittle form of pancreatogenic diabetes) and stone formation. Causes of chronic tropical pancreatitis include:

  • Malnutrition
  • Ingestion of cyanogenic glycosides in cassava
  • Exposure to hydrocarbons released from kerosene or paraffin lamps

Tropical pancreatitis is histologically indistinguishable from chronic alcoholic pancreatitis.

questions.text: Hereditary chronic pancreatitis is caused by the mutation of:
questions.solution:
Hereditary chronic pancreatitis is caused by the mutation of PRSS1 (protease serine 1).

Hereditary pancreatitis is an autosomal dominant disorder, associated with a gain-of-function mutation in the cationic trypsinogen gene (PRSS1) on chromosome 7q. This leads to intrapancreatic activation of trypsinogen and the production of the degradation-resistant form of trypsin.

PRSS1 mutation accounts for about two-thirds of cases of hereditary pancreatitis. There is an increased risk of developing pancreatic cancer, particularly if the patient smokes tobacco. 

Option B: Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 7, and it regulates bicarbonate and chloride concentrations in respiratory and pancreatic secretions. 

  • Homozygous CFTR muta­tions result in cystic fibrosis
  • Heterozygous mild CFTR mutations predis­pose to pancreatic exocrine insufficiency and chronic pancreatitis

Options C and D: Serine peptidase inhibitor Kazal type 1 (SPINK1) or pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor (PSTI) is associated with tropical calcific pancreatitis as well idiopathic chronic pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old diabetic patient presented with complaints of recurrent abdominal pain and weight loss. Investigations showed features suggestive of obstructive jaundice and MRI revealed the following abnormality. All of the statements are true regarding the given condition except:

choices.text: It is likely to resolve spontaneously
Serum IgG4 is elevated in type 2
Corticosteroids are the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
The clinical features and characteristic sausage-shaped appearance of the pancreas on the T2 weighted image are diagnostic of autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP). Serum IgG4 is normal in type 2 AIP. It is elevated in type 1 AIP.

Autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the pancreas. Patients present with features of obstructive jaundice, weight loss, and mild abdominal pain.

CT scan or MRI showing a diffuse enlarged, sausage-shaped pancreas is characteristic of autoimmune pancreatitis.

Serum IgG4 level is considered the best serological marker for AIP.

Most of the cases resolve spontaneously. However, corticosteroid therapy is the treatment of choice as it causes increased remission of AIP. Also, AIP is associated with gastric ulcer formation as there are abundant IgG4 levels. Hence NSAIDs are not part of the management.

They are of two types:

questions.text: The Rosemont criteria for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis is based on:
questions.solution:
Rosemont’s criteria for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis is based on endoscopic ultrasonographic (EUS) findings.

Related Pearl: Rosemontâ€™s criteria for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis

  Parenchymal features Ductal features
Major criteria Major A criteria:
  • Hyperechoic foci with post-acoustic shadowing
Major B criteria:
  • Honeycombing lobularity
 Major A criteria:
  • Main pancreatic duct calculi
Minor criteria
  • Hyperechoic, non-shadowing foci ≥3 mm in length and width
  • Lobularity including three or more noncontiguous lobules in the body or tail
  • Pancreatic cysts ≥2 mm in short axis
  • At least three strands*

   *Strands are defined as hyperechoic lines ≥3 mm in length seen in at least two different directions in the body or tail of the pancreas.
  • Irregular main pancreatic duct (MPD) contour
  • Dilated side branches+
  • Main pancreatic duct dilation (≥3.5 mm in the body or ≥1.5 mm in the tail)
  • Hyperechoic MPD margin >50% of the main pancreatic duct in the body and tail.

 +≥3 tubular anechoic structures, each one ≥1 mm in width, budding from MPD
  Diagnosis of Chronic Pancreatitis:
  • Consistent with chronic pancreatitis
    • 1 major A criterion + ≥3 minor criteria
    • 1 major A criterion + major B criterion
    • 2 major A criteria
  • Suggestive of chronic pancreatitis (requires imaging for confirmation)
    • 1 major A criterion + <3 minor criteria
    • 1 major B criterion + ≥3 minor criteria
    • ≥5 minor criteria
  • Indeterminate for chronic pancreatitis (requires imaging for confirmation)
    • 3-4 minor criteria in the absence of major criteria
    • Major B criterion + <3 minor criteria
  •  Normal

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic tests have the highest sensitivity and specificity to diagnose chronic pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
The diagnostic test with the best sensitivity and specificity for chronic pancreatitis is the secretin test.

Secretin is a hormone secreted by the small intestines. It normally stimulates the pancreas to secrete a fluid with a high concentration of bicarbonate. Secretin stimulation test is a test that measures the ability of the pancreas to respond to secretin.

In order to perform the test, a tube is passed into the duodenum. Secretin is administered intravenously and the contents of the duodenal secretions are aspirated and analyzed over a period of about 2 hours. The test becomes abnormal when ≥60% of the pancreatic exocrine function has been lost. This usually correlates well with the onset of chronic abdominal pain. 

Other investigations to diagnose chronic pancreatitis:

Pancreatic calcifications can be seen on abdominal X-rays.

Endoscopic ultrasound showing the presence of four or more of these following features is highly suggestive of chronic pancreatitis:

  • Presence of stones
  • Visible side branches
  • Cysts
  • Lobularity
  • An irregular main pancreatic duct
  • Hyperechoic foci and strands
  • Dilatation of the main pancreatic duct
  • Hyperechoic margins of the main pancreatic duct

An abdominal CT scan is the initial modality of choice for diagnosing chronic pancreatitis. CT or MRI scan will show the outline of the gland, the main area of damage, and the possibilities for surgical correction.

The investigation of choice for chronic pancreatitis is MRCP with secretin stimulation. ERCP is the gold-standard investigation. They help in identifying the presence of biliary obstruction and the state of the pancreatic duct.

questions.text: All of the following are tests used to diagnose exocrine deficiency of the pancreas except:
questions.solution:
sFLT-1 (soluble FMS like tyrosine kinase-1) is not used to test pancreatic exocrine deficiency. sFLT-1 is a marker used for pre-eclampsia.

Tests for pancreatic exocrine deficiency
Direct tests:
  • Lundh test
 The pancreatic secretion is directly measured following a test meal
  • Secretin or CCK stimulation test
 Following intravenous injection of secretin or CCK, the pancreatic secretion is measured
Indirect tests:
  • Nitroblue tetrazolium–para-aminobenzoic acid (NBT–PABA) test
 The NBT-PABA is administered orally and degraded in the gut by a pancreatic enzyme. The breakdown product (PABA) is absorbed by the intestine and excreted in the urine. Its urinary value is measured.
  • Pancreolauryl test 
 Works on the similar principle of NBT-PABA
  • Measurement of the fecal elastase
 A value below 100 μg/g establishes the diagnosis of severe pancreatic exocrine insufficiency
  • Fecal fat and weight estimation test

questions.text: A 65-year-old man who had multiple episodes of pancreatitis presented with a history of mild epigastric pain and the presence of foul-smelling greasy stools for the past 5 months. MRCP showed the presence of a chain of lake appearance in the pancreas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chain of lakes appearance on pancreatography (ERCP or MRCP) is diagnostic of chronic pancreatitis. 

In chronic pancreatitis, there are multiple strictures and stones in the pancreatic duct. This leads to the alternate stenosis and dilatation of the pancreatic duct leading to the chain of lakes appearance.

questions.text:
A patient with chronic pancreatitis can develop all of the following complications, except:
  1. Portal vein thrombosis
  2. Renal artery stenosis
  3. Fistulae
  4. Duodenal obstruction
  5. Insulinoma
questions.solution:
Renal artery stenosis and insulinoma are not complications of chronic pancreatitis.

Complications of chronic pancreatitis:

Intrapancreatic complications:

  • Pseudocysts
    • Duodenal or gastric obstruction
    • Thrombosis of splenic vein
    • Abscess
    • Perforation
    • Erosion into the visceral artery
  • Inflammatory mass in the head of the pancreas
    • Bile duct stenosis
    • Portal vein thrombosis
    • Duodenal obstruction
  • Duct strictures and/or stones
    • Ductal hypertension and dilatation
  • Pancreatic carcinoma

Extrapancreatic complications:

  • Pancreatic duct leak with ascites or fistula
  • Pseudocyst extension beyond lesser sac into mediastinum, retroperitoneum, lateral pericolic spaces, pelvis, or adjacent viscera

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the complications of chronic pancreatitis?

choices.text: All the complications of acute pancreatitis can occur in patients with chronic pancreatitis.
Calcium oxalate is the most common type of stone in chronic pancreatitis.
At least 90% of acinar cells should be lost before malabsorption symptoms manifest.

questions.solution:
Calcium carbonate stone is the most common type of stone formed in chronic pancreatitis.

Calcium and bicarbonate ions are normally present in pancreatic juice in high concentrations. Lithostathine is a potent inhibitor of calcium carbonate crystal formation. In alcoholics and in patients with alcoholic chronic pancreatitis, lithostathine expression and secretion are dramatically inhibited leading to calcification.

Other complications of chronic pancreatitis:

  • Exocrine insufficiency - At least 90% of the gland needs to be dysfunctional before malabsorption symptoms manifest like:
    • Fat-soluble vitamin deficiency
    • Bleeding
    • Osteopenia
    • Osteoporosis
  • Endocrine insufficiency - Diabetes mellitus. Exocrine insufficiency usually precedes endocrine insufficiency. 
  • All the complications of acute pancreatitis can occur in patients with chronic pancreatitis.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Chronic Pancreatitis

Abdominal pain: most common symptom

  • Site:
    • If infectious foci are in the head of the pancreas, then epigastric and right subcostal pain is common;
    • If the infection is limited to the left side of the pancreas, left subcostal and back pain are seen.
  • Precipitated by food intake, thus weight loss is also seen.
  • Associated with nausea, vomiting

Exocrine insufficiency:

  • Precedes endocrine insufficiency
  • Correlates with morphological changes
  • Manifests with malabsorption symptoms: steatorrhea, diarrhea.
  • Manifests with signs and symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, such as bleeding, osteopenia, and osteoporosis: Severe cases

Endocrine insufficiency: Diabetes mellitus

questions.text: A young male patient presents with steatorrhea associated with chronic pancreatitis. A stool examination of the patient shows increased fecal fat and decreased fecal elastase. What is the mode of administration of the pancreatic enzymes in this patient?
questions.solution:
The mode of administration of pancreatic enzymes in exocrine pancreatic insufficiency is through an oral route.

Effects of pancreatic enzyme replacement in chronic pancreatitis:

  • Reverses exocrine insufficiency
  • Prevents secondary complications such as metabolic bone disease due to inadequate absorption of the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K
  • Reduces pain due to chronic pancreatitis

Pancreatic enzyme supplementation is done with meals. Non-enteric-coated tablets are degraded by gastric juice and the released enzymes inhibit cholecystokinin (CCK) secretion. This, in turn, decreases the pancreatic secretion and thereby reduces the pain caused due to the increased accumulation of the secretions within the pancreatic duct.

Enteric-coated tablets are not degraded in the proximal small intestine and, hence, might not be effective in reducing CCK secretion and relieving pain.

questions.text: Pain relief in chronic pancreatitis can be obtained by the destruction of:
questions.solution: Celiac plexus block is used for pain relief in chronic pancreatitis as well as pancreatic carcinoma. It can be done using alcohol or other analgesics. It is a safe procedure, but the effect is short-lived.

questions.text: A patient with chronic pancreatitis complains of intractable abdominal pain despite the administration of analgesics. CT scan shows pancreatic head enlargement. A EUS guided fine-needle biopsy ruled out pancreatic malignancy. What will be the preferred management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Beger's procedure is the procedure of choice for patients with chronic pancreatitis, having an associated mass in the head of the pancreas.

Beger's procedure is a duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection. It preserves the function of the foregut. Once the pancreatic head is removed, a Roux-en-Y is created and anastomosed to the rim of the pancreas or duodenum, pancreatic duct, and body and also the bile duct, if involved.

Related Pearl: Resection and Hybrid Surgical Procedures for Chronic Pancreatitis

Beger’s procedure: Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (DPPHR)

  • The completed resection after transection of the pancreatic neck and subtotal removal of the pancreatic head, with preservation of the distal common bile duct and duodenum (Marked A).
  • Completion of the reconstruction of the anastomosis to the distal pancreas and to the proximal pancreatic rim by the same Roux limb of the jejunum.

Frey’s procedure:

  • The local resection of the pancreatic head with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (LR-LPJ) provides complete decompression of the entire pancreatic ductal system. Reconstruction is performed with a side-to-side Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy.

Warren’s modification of Beger’s procedure:

Berne modification (Beger + Frey) involves excavation of the central portion of the head without formal division of the neck.

(image below)

Hamburg modification of Frey’s procedure

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with intractable pain associated with chronic pancreatitis. MRCP shows the chain of lakes appearance. What will be the preferred management in this patient?

choices.text: Resection of pancreatic tail and pancreatojejunostomy

questions.solution:
The pancreatic duct dilation observed on pancreatography for chronic pancreatitis is classically described as a chain of lakes, which reflects the presence of multiple dilations and stenoses.

When it is accompanied by intractable pain, this condition is best treated with side-to-side Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy, also known as the modified Puestow procedure or lateral pancreaticojejunostomy.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with dull aching epigastric pain. He gives a history of acute abdominal pain following a binge of alcohol 5 weeks back which was managed conservatively. On examination, he appears icteric and a firm mass was palpable in the epigastrium. His CT scan is given below.  Which of the following statements is false about his condition?

choices.text: Cyst wall is lined by squamous epithelium.
Splenic artery is the most common artery involved.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of acute pancreatitis, epigastric mass, and the CT image showing a cyst is suggestive of pancreatic pseudocyst. The capsule of the cyst is composed of collagen and granulation tissue, and it is not lined by epithelium. Hence, it is called a pseudocyst.

Pseudocysts are post-inflammatory cysts that arise following an attack of mild acute pancreatitis. Formation of a pseudocyst requires 4 weeks or more from the onset of acute pancreatitis. They are also the most common complication of chronic pancreatitis.

Pseudocysts are usually solitary and most commonly seen in the lesser omental sac. The most common artery involved is the splenic artery.

 Complications of pancreatic pseudocyst include:

  • Abscess
  • Systemic sepsis
  • GI bleeding
  • Fistula formation
  • Peritonitis
  • Obstructive jaundice
  • Bowel obstruction
  • Hemorrhage into the cyst
  • Hemoperitoneum

Pancreatic pseudo­cysts can be distinguished from cystic neoplasms by having high amylase levels and absence of mucin and low serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels.

questions.text: A young man is incidentally found to have a pseudocyst of the pancreas on abdominal ultrasound during a master health check-up. The size of the pseudocyst is 5 cm and is located in the tail of the pancreas. Past history is notable for two episodes of acute pancreatitis. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Observation is the preferred treatment in this case since the size of the pseudocyst is <6 cm and is arising from the tail of the pancreas.

Indications for conservative management in pancreatic pseudocyst:

  • Asymptomatic patients
  • Pseudocysts smaller than 6 cm (according to Bailey)
  • Located on the tail
  • No evidence of pancreatic duct obstruction or communication with the main pancreatic duct

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain and severe non-bilious vomiting. He was treated for upper abdominal pain 5 weeks ago.  CT scan reveals a pancreatic pseudocyst of size 8 cm in close proximity to the stomach with secondary pressure effects.  What is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best treatment option for this patient would be to perform a cystogastrostomy since the size of the tumor is greater than 6 cm and in close proximity to the stomach.

Interventions in pseudocyst are required when:

  • Complicated by infection
  • Presence of a mass effect 
  • Diameter increasing in size or greater than 6 cm
  • Recurrence following the previous resection

Endoscopic drainage is usually curative. 

Feature

Treatment approach

Close contact (<1 cm) with the stomach

Transgastric drainage

Close contact (<1 cm) with the duodenum

Transduodenal drainage

Communicating with the main pancreatic duct

Transpapillary drainage

Pancreatic duct stricture associated with a pancreatic pseudocyst

Endoscopic dilation and stent placement

Surgical drainage is done if endoscopy is contraindicated or has failed.

In this cystogastrostomy, an anterior gastrostomy is performed. Once the pseudocyst is located, it is drained through the posterior wall of the stomach using a linear stapler. The defect in the anterior wall of the stomach is closed in two layers.

The image shows the procedure involved in cystogastrostomy.

Cystoduodenostomy is done when pseudocyst is adjacent to the duodenum, or concern about disrupting pancreatic ductal entry into the duodenum.

Roux-en-Y Cystojejunostomy is generally done for cysts that are neither in close proximity to the stomach and nor to the duodenum. This is generally preferred as the last resort as it is associated with a lot of complications. 

Percutaneous drainage to the exterior under radiological guidance is associated with a high recurrence rate and high incidence of pancreatic-cutaneous fistula. Hence, it is not usually done.

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with recurrent abdominal pain radiating to the back and passage of dark-colored stools. He has pallor and mild epigastric tenderness on palpation. Blood investigations show severe anemia and high serum lipase. CT scan reveals a pancreatic pseudoaneurysm and subsequent endoscopy shows blood near the ampulla of Vater. Identify the false statement about his condition:

choices.text: ERCP is the gold standard investigation.
Coil embolization is done only in stable patients.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hemosuccus pancreaticus. CT angiography is the gold standard in diagnosing hemosuccus pancreaticus.

Haemosuccus pancreaticus, also known as pseudohaemobilia, is a rare cause of GI bleeding, due to blood originating from the pancreatic duct into the duodenum via the ampulla of Vater. It is usually caused by the erosion of a pancreatic pseudocyst into the splenic artery.

In hemosuccus pancreatitis, abdominal pain radiating to the back accompanied by melena is the most typical presentation. The pain usually has an up and down pattern, which means it changes in intensity over time. This is due to the transient closure of pancreatic ducts. Other features include:

  • Hematochezia
  • Hematemesis
  • Anemia
  • Jaundice
  • A palpable pulsatile mass with a thrill murmur
  • Retroperitoneal bleeding

Laboratory values show elevated lipase and low hemoglobin levels. The diagnosis is mainly through imaging modalities like upper GI endoscopy, ERCP, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), and contrast-enhanced CT scan.

CT angiography is the gold standard diagnostic tool. It helps to localize the site of bleed and plan the management accordingly.

Once the bleeding source is identified, hemodynamically stable patients are managed by coil embolization, balloon tamponade, or stent placement.

Hemodynamically unstable patients are managed by distal pancreatectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about this procedure done for pancreatic pseudocyst?

choices.text: Failure to respond to an endoscopic treatment is an indication.
Defect in the anterior wall of the stomach is closed in two layers.
The pseudocyst is drained through the anterior wall of the stomach.
Hemorrhage is the major complication expected.

questions.solution:
The image shows cystogastrostomy, which is done for the pancreatic pseudocyst. The pseudocyst is drained through the posterior wall of the stomach.

Surgery in pseudocyst is indicated for patients who fail to respond to endoscopic treatment.

Pancreatic pseudocysts closely attached to the stomach should be treated with a cystogastrostomy. In this procedure, an anterior gastrostomy is performed. Once the pseudocyst is located, it is drained through the posterior wall of the stomach using a linear stapler. The defect in the anterior wall of the stomach is closed in two layers.

Hemorrhage is the major complication expected post-surgery.

questions.text: Milwaukee classification is used for the assessment of:
questions.solution:
Milwaukee classification is used for the assessment of sphincter of Oddi dysfunction.

Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction or dyskinesia (SOD) is a clinical syndrome in which pain, biochemical abnormalities, and dilatation of the bile duct and/or pancreatic duct are attributed to abnormal functions of the sphincter of Oddi.

SOD may result from stenosis of the sphincter or from dysmotility. Scarring or stenosis of the sphincter can result from the passage of stones, pancreatitis, or prior endoscopic sphincterotomies. 

Milwaukee classification of the sphincter of Oddi dysfunction (SOD) : 

Biliary type SOD
  Biliary-type pain Abnormal LFT (a) Dilated CBD (b) Delayed drainage(c)
Type I + + + +
Type II + One or two of (a), (b) and (c)
Type III + None of (a), (b) and (c)
 
  1.  ALT and AST levels are > 2 times normal on ≥ 2 occasions
  2. CBD diameter > 12 mm on USG or > 10mm on cholangiography
  3. Delayed drainage (> 45 min) of contrast on ERCP while supine
Pancreatic type SOD
  Pancreatic-type pain Abnormal LFT (a) Dilated pancreatic duct (b) Delayed drainage(c)
Type I + + + +
Type II + One or two of (a), (b) and (c)
Type III + None of (a), (b) and (c)
 
  1. Amylase and/ or Lipase levels are > 2 times normal on ≥ 2 occasions
  2. Dilated pancreatic duct diameter: head > 6 mm and body > 5 mm
  3. Delayed drainage (> 9 min) of contrast while in prone position
  • Type I SOD is usually managed by Sphincterotomy. Whether such patients should undergo dual sphincterotomies (biliary and pancreatic) is debatable.
  • Type II SOD is usually assessed by a manometry first, followed by surgical or medical management based on manometry findings.
  • Type III SOD is difficult to manage. Surgical management, such as sphincterotomy has variable outcomes with response rates ranging from 8% to 65%. Medical management in the form of nifedipine, proton-pump inhibitor, botulinum toxin injection, etc. does not have long-term benefits as well.

Note:

Cystic tumors of the pancreas are classified according to KloÌˆppel’s classification system.

Choledochal cysts are classified according to the Todani classification system.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the main pancreatic duct.

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is performed using a side-viewing fibreoptic duodenoscope. The ampulla of Vater is intubated, and contrast injected into the biliary and pancreatic ducts to display the anatomy radiologically.

ERCP is helpful for:

  • Direct opacification of bile ducts and pancreatic ducts
  • Dynamic information during the introduction and drainage of the contrast medium
  • Visual assessment of the duodenum and ampulla of Vater, thereby facilitating biopsy
  • Interventional procedures such as sphincterotomy, stone extraction, biliary stenting, and biliary stricture dilatation

ERCP shows filling of the main pancreatic duct (MPD), common bile duct (B), and gallbladder (G). The MPD and CBD drain into the major papillary (large arrow). The small accessory pancreatic duct (small arrows) drains separately into the minor papilla (arrowhead).

The most common complication of ERCP is acute pancreatitis. The main diagnostic disadvantage with ERCP is the underfilling of ducts above a stricture.
